name: SICILIAN DEFENSE
idea: Black refuses the symmetry of 1...e5 and fights for the center with the c-pawn. After d4 cxd4 Nxd4, Black has exchanged a wing pawn (c) for a central pawn (d) - excellent deal! This creates an immediate imbalance: White has more space in the center, but Black has a queenside pawn majority and the semi-open c-file. This is the most combative opening and the most played at the highest level.
errors_white: Playing d4 without Nf3 first: after ...cxd4 Qxd4?? ...Nc6 gains time on the Queen
Ignoring the ...b5-b4 counter-attack: Black can chase the Nc3 and create weaknesses
Pushing pawns without developing: premature f4-f5 or g4-g5 advance leaves the King exposed
errors_black: Playing ...d5 too early: after exd5 Qxd5, the Queen gets chased by Nc3 and White develops with tempo
Neglecting the development of the Nf6: this Knight is crucial for control of d5 and e4
Letting a White Knight settle on d5: without Nf6 to exchange it, this Knight becomes dominant
development: Develop quickly - controls d5, attacks e4, essential in all variations
Choose between ...d6 (solid, Scheveningen/Najdorf) or ...d5 in one move (aggressive)
Fianchetto ...g6/...Bg7 (Dragon) or ...Be7 (classical) depending on the variation
Develop to c6 (classical) or d7 (Scheveningen) to support ...e5
The Ra8 goes to c8 for the semi-open c-file - pressure on c2
Kingside castling is usual, but queenside castling is possible in certain variations

traps.name: Siberian Trap
traps.desc: Alapin: 2.c3 d5 3.exd5 Qxd5 4.d4 Nf6?? 5.Na3! The Na3 goes to b5, attacking c7. AVOID: Play 4...e6! or 4...Nc6 instead of Nf6 to control b5.

traps.name: Dragon Trap
traps.desc: Yugoslav Attack: if Black plays ...Rc8 without preparation, Bxf6! Bxf6 Nd5! is devastating. AVOID: Play ...Rfc8 and ...Ne5 first before ...Rc8.

traps.name: Najdorf Trap
traps.desc: After 6.Bg5 e6 7.f4 Qb6?? 8.Qd2! (or Nb3) the Queen is misplaced, b6 and f7 become weak. AVOID: Play ...Be7 or ...Nbd7 before bringing out the Queen.

variants.name: Dragon
variants.uci: e2e4 c7c5 g1f3 d7d6 d2d4 c5d4 f3d4 g8f6 b1c3 g7g6
variants.white_plan: Yugoslav Attack! f3, Be3, Qd2, 0-0-0 then g4-g5-h4-h5 to open the h-file and mate on h7/h8.
variants.black_plan: The Bg7 is a monster on the long diagonal. Play ...Rc8, ...Qa5, ...Nc6-e5 and push ...b5-b4 to counter-attack.

variants.name: Najdorf
variants.uci: e2e4 c7c5 g1f3 d7d6 d2d4 c5d4 f3d4 g8f6 b1c3 a7a6
variants.white_plan: Several options: 6.Be3 (English Attack), 6.Bg5 (Poisoned Pawn), 6.Be2 (Classical), 6.f3 (Slow English). Central pressure and play on both wings.
variants.black_plan: Maximum flexibility! ...a6 prepares ...b5 and prevents Bb5/Nb5. Then choose between ...e5 (space) or ...e6 (solid) depending on White.

variants.name: Sveshnikov
variants.uci: e2e4 c7c5 g1f3 b8c6 d2d4 c5d4 f3d4 g8f6 b1c3 e7e5
variants.white_plan: After Ndb5 d6, the Knight settles on d5 via c3. Exploit the d5 hole and the weakness of the backward d6 pawn.
variants.black_plan: Accept the weakness on d5 for activity! The bishop pair, the f5 square for the Knight and the ...f5 push more than compensate.
